content: 1. According to the Iranian Constitution, their Supreme Leader - Ali Hoseyni Khamenei is their highest leader in charge of the country. Their President (Ahmadinejad) is more like an elected VP or Secretary of State (like Hillary Clinton). He doesn't have any control over the armed forces or nuclear policy. 2. Ahmadinejad is up for reelection on 12 June 2009. According to the Iranian press, he has a slight lead in the polls. The Iranians are not all that happy with him. If Obama plays his cards right(and especially avoids confrontation), he could push him over the edge. I'm sure they are working on some strategy for his meetings.

content: On this topic Let us say Iran is making a nuclear bomb. Will we do anything about? I look at Iraq (taking out the crap if Pres Bush "lied"( which I do not believe so)) and the threat was real and a lot of countries said the same. Yet the fresh stuff was not found. Now concerning Iran and this admin...they would be stupid to not go for a bomb IMO. From a global perspective it is better to go in and prevent Iran from getting a bomb now. But I do not think we will and I do not think Iran will immediately use their bomb until they have more than one. That is when I would really begin to worry (more than I am now about Israel) so…what political game can have an impact?

content: quote: Has the Guardian Council finally tired of Afterdinnermint's posturing then do you think? There had been signs of it (he's been slapped down a couple of times) but I thought they were going to give him another crack at it, albeit with a reduced majority. Frankly, I think their main concern is to hold elections that make them look good. That is to say, they cannot overtly interfere after they've accepted the candidates. (They can always block the new president's actions afterwards, when there's not so many eyes on them.) I think it comes down to whether the reformists can unite behind one candidate, and whether the reformist candidate can appeal to moderate conservatists. Also, Khatami stepping down made it a lot more difficult for the principlists to unite against the reformist candidate, while giving Mousavi a lot more votes. Just this week there were reports of the major reformist organizations expressing support for Mousavi, and that he may also get principlist votes. Of course, Khamenei might decide to "pull rank" late in the election and get the Revolutionary Guards and Basij to vote his way. As of now, he has explicitly stated that even though he agrees with current government actions, it shouldn't be seen as an endorsement for re-election. quote: That said it could be that without the Bush administration to kick against it might be that they're worried about an America that can't be portrayed as overtly threatening. Obama's invitation to talk might have spiked one of their main weapons. They can still use Israel as an outside threath to unite the voters behind the current president. Conveniently, the more Ahmadinejad releases reports of advances in nuclear technology, the more threats there will be from Israel.
